  "triples": [
    {"s":"X-ray tube", "p":"produces", "o":"Bremsstrahlung radiation", "modalities":["text"], "confidence":1.0, "evidence":"The first mechanism is called Bremsstrahlung radiation, a German word meaning 'braking radiation.'"},
    {"s":"X-ray tube", "p":"produces", "o":"Characteristic radiation", "modalities":["text"], "confidence":1.0, "evidence":"The second mechanism is called characteristic radiation, sometimes explained in terms of the photoelectric effect."},
    {"s":"Bremsstrahlung radiation", "p":"represents", "o":"continuous radiation", "modalities":["text"], "confidence":1.0, "evidence":"Since the amount of bending can vary, the emitted X-rays span a continuous range of energies. That’s why Bremsstrahlung is also called continuous radiation."},
    {"s":"Characteristic radiation", "p":"depends_on", "o":"photoelectric effect", "modalities":["text"], "confidence":1.0, "evidence":"In this case, a high-energy primary electron collides with an inner-shell electron of the tungsten atom

evidence: Since the amount of bending can vary, the emitted X-rays span a continuous range of energies. That’s why Bremsstrahlung is also called continuous radiation.
